title: 107_hr4141
content: The Act is titled the "Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as Corporation, Red Rock, Red Rock Map, and Secretary. SEC. 3. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. The Congress finds Red Rock to be a significant natural resource that must be protected for future generations. The Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998 aimed to enhance Red Rock. The Corporation owns land on Red Rock's eastern boundary and is developing a master-planned community, including 1,071 acres of high-ground lands intended for Red Rock. The Corporation owns land on Red Rock's eastern boundary and is developing a master-planned community. This includes 1,071 acres of high-ground lands intended for Red Rock, which the Corporation has volunteered to forgo development on. They propose that the United States acquire title to preserve the high-ground lands in perpetuity for the protection and expansion of Red Rock. The Corporation has volunteered to forgo developing high-ground lands and suggests the United States acquire title to preserve them for Red Rock's protection and expansion. The Act aims to exchange lands between the United States and the Corporation, protect Red Rock, and fulfill the purposes of relevant conservation acts. The Act proposes a land exchange between the United States and the Corporation to protect and expand Red Rock for conservation purposes. The Corporation offers approximately 1,082 acres of nonfederal land to the United States for incorporation into the NCA. In return, the Corporation will receive approximately 998 acres of Federal lands, and Clark County, Nevada will receive approximately 1,221 acres of Federal lands for a park. The conveyances must be completed within 90 days of the offer. The Secretary will convey approximately 1,221 acres of Federal lands to Clark County, Nevada for a park, as depicted on the Red Rock Map. The private and Federal properties will be conveyed simultaneously. The Secretary will keep the Red Rock Map on file for public inspection. The Corporation must be responsible for hazardous materials removal on the conveyed property. As a condition of the conveyance, the Secretary will require the Corporation to handle hazardous materials removal and provide a boundary survey within 90 days. The Secretary will also require conditions for lands conveyed to Clark County. The Secretary will require a boundary survey for the common boundary between the parcels of land to be conveyed to Clark County. The lands transferred must be used as a public park or part of a public regional trail system, with reversion to the United States if used inconsistently. SEC. 5. STATUS AND MANAGEMENT OF LANDS. Upon enactment of this Act, the Secretary will administer the Flood Control Detention Basin Lands depicted on the Red Rock Map as part of Red Rock, excluding those used for the Corps of Engineers R-4 Detention Basin, in accordance with relevant laws. Upon acquisition of lands by the United States, the Secretary will administer them as part of Red Rock in compliance with specified Acts. Upon acquisition of lands under this Act, the Secretary will administer them as part of Red Rock in accordance with relevant laws. New maps will be created to show the modified boundaries of Red Rock, available for review at designated Bureau of Land Management offices. A conforming amendment is made to the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Establishment Act of 1990. The boundaries of Red Rock will be modified, with new maps available for review at designated Bureau of Land Management offices in Las Vegas and Reno. A conforming amendment is made to the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Establishment Act of 1990. SEC. 6. GENERAL PROVISIONS. The Secretary must review an appraisal and any difference in values will be reimbursed. The land exchange is subject to existing rights, and technical corrections can be made to the Red Rock Map. The Secretary can make technical corrections to the Red Rock Map. The Act allows for the withdrawal of Federal lands from public land and mining laws, subject to valid existing rights. The House of Representatives passed the bill on October 1, 2002.
